tips.title: Travel Tips in Korea
tips.subtitle: What would you like to know?

payment.title: Payment Guide
list: Most shops, restaurants, and convenience stores accept international cards (VISA, Mastercard, JCB, UnionPay, etc.).
Markets, small restaurants, and rural areas may not accept cards, so it's recommended to carry some cash.

emergency.title: How to Use Emergency Numbers 112/119

list: Report crimes, traffic accidents, lost items
Use for fire, emergency medical, rescue situations
Automatic location tracking when you call

emergency.additionalTipContent: 1330 is a 24/7 multilingual tourist helpline operated by the Korea Tourism Organization. In emergencies, it can provide interpretation support through a three-way call with 112 or 119.

transportCard.title: How to Use Transportation Cards (eZL, T-money)
rechargeableCardList: Most widely used transportation cards in Korea. Buy once and recharge multiple times.
Where to buy: convenience stores (GS25, CU, 7-Eleven, Emart24, etc.)
Usable on subways, buses, airport trains, and some taxis
Compatible in most areas including Seoul, Busan, Jeju
Can be recharged with cash only
Remaining balance can be refunded at some convenience stores minus a fee
Can be used at some convenience stores
Transfer discounts available between bus and subway
transportCard.rechargeableCardRecommendation: Best option if you plan to use public transport multiple times.

ezl.title: eZL
list: IC type: includes payment chip, usable for general purchases
RF type: no chip, usable only for public transport and some convenience stores
If registered on eZL site, balance can be refunded when reported lost

tmoney.title: T-money
list: RF type: no chip, usable only for public transport and some convenience stores
If registered on T-money site, balance can be refunded when reported lost

singleUseTicketList: One-time-use card for Seoul subway only
Can be purchased from ticket machines inside subway stations
Includes a 500 KRW deposit (e.g., 1,250 fare + 500 deposit = 1,750 total)
Refundable 500 KRW at deposit return machines at your destination station
transportCard.singleUseTicketRecommendation: Useful if you're using the subway just once or twice!

embassy.title: Embassy Contacts (by Country)
embassy.description: Contact info and addresses of major embassies in Korea. You can seek help in case of loss, accidents, or emergencies.
embassy.noteContent: Embassies operate on weekdays only. In case of emergency, you can reach them via emergency contact numbers.

hospital.title: Finding Hospitals & Pharmacies + Location Info
pharmacyList: You can buy basic medicine (like cold medicine) at pharmacies, but antibiotics require a doctor’s prescription.
Most pharmacies offer basic English communication.
Some convenience stores also sell basic medication.
foreignerFriendlyList: Seoul National University Hospital: English, Chinese, Japanese support
Yonsei Medical Center: Operates an international clinic
Samsung Medical Center: Foreigners-only reception desk
Asan Medical Center: Provides interpretation service
mainHospitalsList: Information on hospitals with foreigner services is currently being updated. In emergencies, call 119 for transport to the nearest ER.
